3.  Proof of Theorem 2
In the following work we shall require an important result originally due to Gilbarg,  which is stated below as Proposition II.  For the proof see [ 6 ],  Sections 2—5,  where in fact a considerably stronger result appears,  and for related theorems see [ 10 ],  Section 7. 
Proposition IL Let D be a bounded domain in E^ whose boundary is of class C^,  Consider the Dirichlet problem for the minimal surface equation in D with boundary values a f on Г J where a is a constant and f is a function of class C^. 
Suppose that for 0 ^ a ^ i one can establish an a priori bound
\Vu\ < M for x^D
for the gradient of any solution which is continuously differentiable in the closure of Z ),  where M is independent of a.  Then there exists a solution of the minimal surface equation in D which takes the boundary values f on Г and is of class C^ in the closure of D, 
A similar result was obtained by Bernstein for the case of two independent variables ( see [ 1 ],  pages 233—236 ). 
From Proposition II and Lemma 3 it follows that the boundary value problem for the minimal surface equation is solvable provided Г and / are of class C^ and the condition H ^ —ocljbte^ is satisfied ( we can then take M = 4e^ ).  Lemma 4 below gives a more useful formulation of this result,  and indeed establishes Theorem 2 for the case where the boundary and the data are of class C^. 
We require some preliminary definitions.  Let

the right hand sides depending only on the domain D,  the assigned data,  and the dimension ( see Section 2 ).  Also put

where H is the mean curvature of Г.  We now define

As a function of the mean curvature of Г,  the quantity ^ is continuous in the extended reals,  tends to zero as the minimum mean curvature tends to minus infinity,  and is infinite when the mean curvature is everywhere non - negative. 
Lemma 4.  Let D be a bounded domain in E^ whose boundary is of class C^.  Then the Dirichlet problem for the minimal surface equation in D is well posed for C^ boundary values f whenever
